channel.title: Comments on: My New Book Just Came Out-Judaism and Other Religions
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Jeff Wild
item.dc:creator: Jeff Wild
item.description: Speaking of books, I just got your book <i>Thinking God</i> off my shelf and am thinking of rereading it. It is almost 10 years old. What are your thoughts about it from your perspective today? Does it have anything to say as a counterpoint to the Suburban religion you discuss in a recent post?
item.content:encoded: Speaking of books, I just got your book Thinking God off my shelf and am thinking of rereading it. It is almost 10 years old. What are your thoughts about it from your perspective today? Does it have anything to say as a counterpoint to the Suburban religion you discuss in a recent post?

item.title: By: chakira
item.dc:creator: chakira
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2010/02/13/my-new-book-just-came-out-judaism-and-other-religions/#comment-597">Alan Brill</a>.
What would Bourdieu say about this AMZN suggestions convo? Its the dissipation of the non-subject at the center of taste, in favor of an interpassive taste-for-non-subjects.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Alan Brill.

What would Bourdieu say about this AMZN suggestions convo? Its the dissipation of the non-subject at the center of taste, in favor of an interpassive taste-for-non-subjects.

item.title: By: Jeff Wild
item.dc:creator: Jeff Wild
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2010/02/13/my-new-book-just-came-out-judaism-and-other-religions/#comment-597">Alan Brill</a>.
<i>To Change the World: The Irony, Tragedy, and Possibility of Christianity in the Late Modern World</i> sounds like an interesting read. I hope you review on your blog.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Alan Brill.

To Change the World: The Irony, Tragedy, and Possibility of Christianity in the Late Modern World sounds like an interesting read. I hope you review on your blog.

item.title: By: Alan Brill
item.dc:creator: Alan Brill
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2010/02/13/my-new-book-just-came-out-judaism-and-other-religions/#comment-596">Jeff Wild</a>.
Thanks, if enough people order it then it might come down a few dollars. Since, I just ordered James Davidson Hunter, To Change the World: The Irony, Tragedy, and Possibility of Christianity in the Late Modern World, I get a very different list.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jeff Wild.

Thanks, if enough people order it then it might come down a few dollars.
Since, I just ordered James Davidson Hunter, To Change the World: The Irony, Tragedy, and Possibility of Christianity in the Late Modern World, I get a very different list.

item.title: By: Jeff Wild
item.dc:creator: Jeff Wild
item.description:
FYI -- Amazon is pushing your book. I just got an email saying:
As someone who has purchased or rated Love and Terror in the God Encounter: The Theological Legacy of Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik by David Hartman, you might like to know that Judaism and Other Religions: Models of Understanding will be released on March 2, 2010.
item.content:encoded:
FYI — Amazon is pushing your book. I just got an email saying:

As someone who has purchased or rated Love and Terror in the God Encounter: The Theological Legacy of Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik by David Hartman, you might like to know that Judaism and Other Religions: Models of Understanding will be released on March 2, 2010.

item.title: By: moshe shoshan
item.dc:creator: moshe shoshan
item.description: Thanbo- I would presume that Schwartz's decision was motivated by professional concerns.
item.content:encoded: Thanbo- I would presume that Schwartz’s decision was motivated by professional concerns.

item.title: By: thanbo
item.dc:creator: thanbo
item.description:
Sometimes I just don't understand people's decisions about which publisher to use - or are academic books also subject to the publisher's whim in accepting them?
E.g., Dov Schwartz' book on the Rav's Ish haHalacha. It was $25 at the Israel Bookshop in Brookline. The Hebrew was a bit beyond me, so I figured I'd wait for the English, but he published the translation with Brill, which costs $173 at Amazon. Brill things are almost always expensive. A bit beyond the range of the consumer, really only for specialists and libraries, I guess. Surely with the wide interest in the Rav, there would have been plenty of market for a cheaper translation in the States?
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I just don’t understand people’s decisions about which publisher to use – or are academic books also subject to the publisher’s whim in accepting them?

E.g., Dov Schwartz’ book on the Rav’s Ish haHalacha. It was $25 at the Israel Bookshop in Brookline. The Hebrew was a bit beyond me, so I figured I’d wait for the English, but he published the translation with Brill, which costs $173 at Amazon. Brill things are almost always expensive. A bit beyond the range of the consumer, really only for specialists and libraries, I guess. Surely with the wide interest in the Rav, there would have been plenty of market for a cheaper translation in the States?

item.title: By: Alan Brill
item.dc:creator: Alan Brill
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://kavvanah.wordpress.com/2010/02/13/my-new-book-just-came-out-judaism-and-other-religions/#comment-589">Michael Makovi</a>.
This is the cheapest it is going to get. If you get it now and it comes down a few cents - you have a price guarantee until March 2 and free shipping. But in a few months the price will probably go up to over $60. So this is the time to order it. I have an institutional order form for 20% off of the 85 list price. For review copies, if you have reviewed before then you know that you have to go through the marketing department of Palgrave.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Michael Makovi.

This is the cheapest it is going to get. If you get it now and it comes down a few cents – you have a price guarantee until March 2 and free shipping.
But in a few months the price will probably go up to over $60.
So this is the time to order it.
I have an institutional order form for 20% off of the 85 list price.
For review copies, if you have reviewed before then you know that you have to go through the marketing department of Palgrave.

item.title: By: Michael Makovi
item.dc:creator: Michael Makovi
item.description:
I'm looking forward to this book, yes indeed I am. I already read Dr. Brill's articles summarizing his thesis, so I'm excited about this book.
Now I just have to find the money to buy it... ;-( I've already got a several-hundred-dollar list of books on Calvin and Locke I want to buy.
item.content:encoded:
I’m looking forward to this book, yes indeed I am. I already read Dr. Brill’s articles summarizing his thesis, so I’m excited about this book.

Now I just have to find the money to buy it… ;-( I’ve already got a several-hundred-dollar list of books on Calvin and Locke I want to buy.

item.title: By: Izgad
item.dc:creator: Izgad
item.description: Amazon has it on sell for just over $50. Is there a way that poor graduate student bloggers could get a review copy. :)
item.content:encoded: Amazon has it on sell for just over $50. Is there a way that poor graduate student bloggers could get a review copy. 🙂
